title: About This Page
text:
Hi! My name is Aashna Patel and I am a rising Junior from Illinois. You can contact me at aashnapatel2008@gmail.com. Visit my Github page: https://github.com/aashna-a-patel
This project was created through Kane’s Data Science Bootcamp

title: Cheeses: Milk type vs Country
text:
Check out cheese production in Germany, Italy, and France with an animated graph showing milk types used. See how cow, sheep, and goat milk affect these cheeses in cool animations. The following data was pulled from the tidyverse package and posted on the TidyTuesday Github. Learn about the different cheese styles and cultural traditions in Europe!









The animated graph provides a clear picture of how cow, sheep, and goat milk influence the variety of cheeses produced in these three countries. More than any other milk type, cow milk is by far the most common. This insight into cheese production underscores the cultural significance of dairy choices in shaping culinary identities across Europe.

title: Sources
text: This data was pulled from TidyTuesday, a Github account which posts new sets of data every week. Specifically, this data came from the dataset ‘cheeses’.

title: Sources
text:
Packages used include:
tidyverse
ggplot2
gganimate
dplyr

Visit the source of this dataset: https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/tree/master
Made with RStudio

title: Types
text:
This next graph is a plot of the type of cheese most commonly made in France, Germany, and Italy, each represented by a color.









This scatter plot provides a clear image of the certain preferences the various countries have when it comes to cheese production. The regions on the x-axis are ones found in all three countries known for making cheese. Concluding from this graph, France has a higher preference of making softer cheeses while Germany has a higher preference of making semi-soft and harder cheeses. Italy does not seem to have much of a preference in cheese type.

title: Flavors
text:
This pie chart shows the distribution of flavors across France, Germany, and Italy combined.









The pie chart displays the distribution of flavors like creamy, nutty, tangy, sweet, and others in common cheese types. It emphasizes creamy and nutty flavors as prevalent, guiding producers in meeting consumer preferences and diversifying product offerings effectively. Among teh flavors, creamy and nutty are the most popular. This helps cheese makers know what consumers prefer and make cheeses that people will want to buy.
